awd_titl_txt: Influence of Structural Ordering and Defects on the Magnetostriction in Strong and Ductile Fe-Based Alloys with Large Low-Field Magnetostriction
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract

This work deals with alloys  that exhibit strain in response to an applied magnetic field or change in magnetization with application of stress. Use of these materials for deploying antenna structures in space, wind and ocean energy harvesting systems, nanopositioning systems and numerous other applications make them an economically important class of metallic materials.  Alloys based on Iron and Gallium metals  have been demonstrated to be an attractive alternative and further development of this class of  alloys requires a large data base of how alloying elements, structure and defects influence composition-structure-property correlations. This project addresses these important issues. The project will further the knowledge that will enable the design and development of a new generation of inexpensive and high performance alloys for use in sensor and actuator applications. The project will further the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students and enhance research opportunities for women and underrepresented minority students.  The project will also have a great impact in a wide range of applications that will utilize these rare-earth free, strong, ductile, low cost and high performance sensor and actuator materials. 

Technical Abstract
 
The project examines how short-range ordering, long-range ordering and structural dislocations can dramatically influence the magnetostriction in FeGa, and other alpha-Fe based magnetostrictive alloy single crystals. We have shown in earlier work that the addition of Ga to Fe results in a large increase in magnetostriction at low applied magnetic fields and that these alloys are strong and ductile. Ongoing investigations also suggest that internal inhomogeneous strains introduced by the structural changes and defects play a much greater role than has been appreciated in determining the magnetostriction in these alloys. The long-term objectives are to gain an improved understanding of magnetostriction in Fe and Fe alloys and formulate the guidelines for the design of alloys with attractive magnetostrictive and mechanical properties. As a part of this effort, the proposed work will focus on a detailed examination of (a) how short range order is changed with thermal treatments and how it influences magnetostriction in Fe-Ga, Fe-Al and Fe-Si alloys, (b) influence of coherent second phases on the  internal strain modulations and how it affects magnetostriction (c) the effect of well-defined crystal defects in particular dislocation structures introduced with controlled single crystal deformation on magnetostriction and (d) Interference contrast imaging of microcellular patterns and how they are influenced by the ordered second phases regions and dislocation arrays. The work envisaged involves alloy preparation by vacuum arc-melting, single crystal growth using Bridgman technique, structural evaluation, magnetic and magnetostriction measurements, and structure-composition-property correlations. Characterization and analysis of the defects will be carried out using transmission electron microscopy. Elastic measurements will be made using the resonance ultrasound spectroscopy technique. Theta-2 theta x-ray diffraction scans, rocking curve scans and x-ray topography measurements will be performed to assess the crystal orientation, short range order and the structural defects.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

In our earlier NSF supported work following our discovery of large magnetostriction in Fe-Ga alloys, we had discovered large magnetostriction also in rare-earth free Fe-W and Fe-Mo alloys. Controlling inhomogeneous elastic strains due to defects and ordering of solute atoms in these solid solution alloys is key to controlling magnetostriction.  In this project, the first-ever quantitative measurements of the short-range ordering (SRO) of the solute atoms up to the 7th shell in Fe-Ga alloys with various Ga contents and thermal history have been successfully carried out.  This has allowed correlation of thermal history and Ga content with magnetostriction in these alloys.  The work confirmed the hypothesis that the difference in the extent of ordering is the source of the observed high sensitivity of magnetostriction with changes in thermal history. Study also further confirmed our earlier work that dislocation arrays introduced by deformation involving a single slip system decrease magnetostriction. These findings have allowed a better understanding of the influence thermal history, Ga content and deformation on magnetostriction and provide valuable insights into the correlations of magnetostrictive responses with increase in the Ga concentration and annealing.  This study opens up a new window of possibilities for using inexpensive non-rare-earth additions to Fe and controlling defects in order to obtain large magnetostrictive strains at low fields, and strong and ductile alloys. This has major implications from both scientific and commercial perspectives. This impacts the areas of metallurgical engineering, physics of magnetism, and magnetostrictive devices.

The theoretical model, computer codes and experimental methodology developed in this work for quantitative determination of SRO can also be applied to all crystalline solid materials and can lead to the understanding of how their properties from electrochemical behavior to structural, corrosion, magnetic and optical behaviors may be influenced by deviation from a random solid solution condition.

This work along with earlier NSF supported work has enabled the design and to the development of a new generation of rare-earth-free, low-cost high performance magnetostrictive alloys with applications in numerous sensor, actuator and energy harvesting applications, replacing rare-earth-rich Terfenol alloys previously the alloy of choice despite its many limitations. This leads to potentially reduced demand on critical element resources.

Broader Impact:

Several avenues for the training and professional development of graduate students were provided by the scope of the project that involved use of unique and wide array of experimental capabilities that range from alloy synthesis, single crystal growth, directional solidification, magnetic, magnetostrictive and physical property characterization, to device development. Graduate students had opportunities to attend MS&T 2016, TMS 2017, and MS&T 2019 conferences. The current student will attend TMS 2022 in San Diego to present two papers.  The project led to a Ph.D. dissertation of one graduate student and an MS thesis of one graduate student as well as training of two additional graduate students who worked on the project for part of the time.  The PhD degree recipient was employed on graduation by Coorstek, an advanced ceramics manufacturer based in Golden, CO and the MS degree recipient on graduation was employed by Curtiss Wright, an aerospace company based in Ithaca.  

The project enhanced course content and student experience in four existing undergraduate- and graduate-courses in Magnetic Materials, Metals Processing, X-ray Diffraction, and Physical Metallurgy. The PI helped ASM International professional society to organize ASM Materials Camp for Teachers in Utah during 2018 and 2019 summers, a 1-week intense workshop for chemistry, physics and science high-school teachers to promote materials science education in schools. About 40 teachers participating were exposed to PI?s research indirectly impacting several hundred students. PI and students helped ASM organize the ASM Minicamp for middle- and high-school students in Salt Lake City and surrounding region during the MS&T 2016 benefitting several hundred students.

This research program was used to strengthen the ongoing magnetic materials research and physical research facilities that provide a safe environment for students and the PI. The project allowed establishment of the capabilities for experimental measurement and modeling of SRO in metals and alloys.

Honors and recognitions received include the University of Utah College of Mines and Earth Science Outstanding Teaching Award for 2016-2017 and the Department of Metallurgical Engineering Outstanding Teaching Distinguished Teaching Award for 2016-2017 to the PI;  appointment of PI as the Associate Dean for Academics, College of Mines and Earth Sciences at the University of Utah for 2017-2023;  appointment of PI as the Vice-Chair of the Editorial Board of International Materials Reviews; and selection of graduate student Andrew to the two-week 20th National School on Neutron and X-ray Scattering held at Argonne National Lab and Oak Ridge National Lab during the summer of 2018 and to the Nature Masterclasses workshop held in Salt Lake City on May 2019; and the College of Mines and Earth sciences? ?Best Laboratory Safety Practices Award for 2017-18.


Last Modified: 08/30/2021
Modified by: Sivaraman Guruswamy
